Wow, that was a quick decision...
Just two month ago my wish/idea was ignor=
ed.

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/archive-crawler/message/6465

Hmmm,=
 may be the wrong person asked...
Anyway, I'm glad it will be done.

Thanks=
, Bernd


--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "steve@..." <steve@...> w=
rote:
>
> heh, i meant "alluded", not "eluded".
> 
> thanks for the further=
 info Erik. now i see the problem. running
> H3/org.archive.io.ArchiveTest,=
 i see that it gives "text/html"
> mimetype in CDX mode for an ARC, but for=
 WARC it reports:
> 
>    application/http; msgtype=3Dresponse
>    applica=
tion/http; msgtype=3Drequest
>    application/warc-fields
> 
> so, i've ope=
ned an issue for us to make sure that
> ArchiveRecordHeader.getMimetype() g=
ives payload-content-type for
> WARCs (for consistency), and to add a metho=
d which still gives
> access to the WARC record container-content-type.
> 
=
> https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1788
> 
> 
> /steve@...
> 
> 
> 
>=
 /steve@...
> 
> On 6/17/10 12:44 PM, Erik Hetzner wrote:
> > At Thu, 17 Ju=
n 2010 12:27:52 -0700,
> > steve@... wrote:
> >>
> >> you want to examine t=
he HTTP header Content-Type contained
> >> _within_ the WARC record, rather=
 than the WARC header
> >> Content-Type.
> >>
> >> the crawl-report reports=
 HTTP header Content-Type(s). WARC files
> >> also contain WARC header Cont=
ent-Type(s) as eluded to by Erik.
> >> there will be a request, response, a=
nd metadata WARC record
> >> header for each target-URI, which also contain=
 their own
> >> Content-Type field.
> >>
> >> e.g. for "WARC-Target-URI: ht=
tp://www.archive.org/" the
> >> following "Content-Type" entries will be re=
ported in a WARC
> >> record (with other selected fields):
> >>
> >> [=E2=
=80=A6]
> >>
> >> org.archive.io.ArchiveRecordHeader.getMimetype() should r=
eport
> >> the mimetype you're interested in.
> >>
> >> hope that helps.
> =
>
> > Hi Steve, all,
> >
> > Thanks for the very clear explanation of the i=
ssue, Steve.
> >
> > I just had another look at this because I will need to=
 be parsing WARC
> > records myself soon.
> >
> > I tested getMimetype - it=
 seems to return the WARC Content-type rather
> > than the body Content-Typ=
e.
> >
> > The WARCIndexer tool bundled with the open source wayback does,
=
> > however, extract the MIME type from the actual response. It does this
>=
 > by parsing the HTTP headers itself. Here is a good starting place to
> >=
 see how to extract the HTTP headers from the WARC record:
> >
> >    https=
://archive-access.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/archive-access/trunk/archive-=
access/projects/wayback/wayback-core/src/main/java/org/archive/wayback/reso=
urcestore/indexer/WARCRecordToSearchResultAdapter.java
> >
> > Hopefully th=
e WARC/ARC API will be cleaned up soon; it is strange to
> > have the same =
method (getMimetype) with completely different
> > semantics.
> >
> > If yo=
u are only using WARCs, an alternative might be to use the WARC
> > tools h=
ere:
> >
> >    http://law.dsi.unimi.it/index.php?option=3Dcom_content&task=
=3Dview&id=3D35&Itemid=3D42
> >
> > Which contains code for parsing the HTT=
P response itself.
> >
> > best, Erik
> >
> >
> >
> > Sent from my free sof=
tware system<http://fsf.org/>.
>
